prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim here to detect the CO(2-1) line in these systems, as this line is bright, and observable in short periods of time at our required angular resolution. As argued above we require relatively high velocity resolution. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$1.28 \kms), which we will bin up to 20 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for bright sources, or increase it to get higher sensitivity. We place our representative spectral window on 12CO(2-1) using this setup. Our lines are wide (upto 900 km/s in some cases), but will easily fit within the ~2500 km/s coverage of an individual window. We place another band on the nearby CS line, which would provide a window on the dense gas conditions in our source (but detection of this line would be an unexpected bonus, and does not drive our time estimate). We will use 16x spectral averaging for this window to reduce the data rate, as this line is expected to be weak. In each sideband we also place a 2GHz spectral window with 31MHz (45 \kms) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

We request intermediate resolution (0.3") observations for this project, using band 6 and the C36-4 array. This will give us ~100pc linear resolution in our targets, allowing us to resolve the inner 300pc area previous authors have found hosts the strongest IMF variation. At this resolution we are also able to resolve the sphere of influence in NGC1684, allowing direct determination of the black-hole mass (if gas is present at suitably small radii). This resolution is also well matched to our ancillary data taken with adaptive optics, providing powerful opportunities to compare and contrast results.
As discussed in detail in the sensitivity estimate part of the technical justification, the largest angular scale we expect in each 20km/s channel is 11". This is larger than the LAS resolvable in the C36-4 array, so we request an additional low resolution track with the 12m array for each object. In NGC1497 HST observations reveal a dust disk which has a minor axis size of 3 arcseconds, less than the LAS for the C36-4 array, and hence we do not request such a track here.

This galaxy has CO(2-1) observations from Davis et al., in prep (see spectrum in Figure 1). From these single dish observations we know the total flux, flux per velocity channel, and line width (listed in Table 1). We aim to map the molecular gas disc, and hence need to know its size to estimate the surface brightness. In NGC1497 HST observations reveal a dust disk 15x3 arcseconds in size, and we use this information to estimate the sensitivity required. Such information is not yet available for the other objects, however. Studies of other ETG samples have suggested that such disks tend to extend to around half of the galaxies effective radius, which in these objects corresponds to between 5 and 11 arcseconds (Table 1). Our observations of CO(1-0) and CO(2-1) (shown in Figure 2) had different beam sizes, and can also be used to infer a rough major axis size of ~11 arcseconds in two sources, and less in the remainder. Experience shows that at the angular resolution we request the sources will be unresolved in each channel along the kinematic axis of the system (tracing the `spider diagram') and thus only the minor axis size is important when estimating the surface brightness sensitivity required. When calculating the required RMS we conservatively assume the galaxies are all observed face on, and thus the average flux per channel is divided over an 11 arcseconds. In reality the minor axis size will likely be less, boosting the resultant signal to noise we will achieve.
In order to calculate the RMS requested we take the integrated intensity of the CO(2-1) line and divide it by the velocity width (see Table 1) to give a mean flux per channel. Spreading this flux over 33 resolution elements (resolving the minor axis size of 11" with a 0.3" beam) and requiring a 3 sigma detection gives us our requested RMS. This estimate is highly conservative, but easily reachable in short observations with ALMA.
The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. We here base our sensitivity estimate on binning to 20 km/s channels, which will yield a typical uncertainty in M/L of ?0.1, allowing an accurate determination of the IMF parameters. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

As argued above we require relatively high velocity resolution. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$1.28 \kms), which we will bin up to 20 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for bright sources, or increase it to get higher sensitivity. We place our representative spectral window on 12CO(2-1) using this setup. Our lines are wide (upto 900 km/s in some cases), but will easily fit within the ~2500 km/s coverage of an individual window. We place another band on the nearby CS line, which would provide a window on the dense gas conditions in our source (but detection of this line would be an unexpected bonus, and does not drive our time estimate). We will use 16x spectral averaging for this window to reduce the data rate, as this line is expected to be weak. In each sideband we also place a 2GHz spectral window with 31MHz (45 \kms) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

This resolution is also well matched to our ancillary data taken with adaptive optics, providing powerful opportunities to compare and contrast results.
As discussed in detail in the sensitivity estimate part of the technical justification, the largest angular scale we expect in each 20km/s channel is 11". In NGC1497 HST observations reveal a dust disk which has a minor axis size of 3 arcseconds, less than the LAS for the C36-4 array, and hence we do not request such a track here.

In order to calculate the RMS requested we take the integrated intensity of the CO(2-1) line and divide it by the velocity width (see Table 1) to give a mean flux per channel. The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. We here base our sensitivity estimate on binning to 20 km/s channels, which will yield a typical uncertainty in M/L of ?0.1, allowing an accurate determination of the IMF parameters. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

We aim here to detect the CO(2-1) line in these systems, as this line is bright, and observable in short periods of time at our required angular resolution. As argued above we require relatively high velocity resolution. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$1.28 \kms), which we will bin up to 20 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for bright sources, or increase it to get higher sensitivity. We place our representative spectral window on 12CO(2-1) using this setup. Our lines are wide (upto 900 km/s in some cases), but will easily fit within the ~2500 km/s coverage of an individual window. We place another band on the nearby CS line, which would provide a window on the dense gas conditions in our source (but detection of this line would be an unexpected bonus, and does not drive our time estimate). In each sideband we also place a 2GHz spectral window with 31MHz (45 \kms) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

We request intermediate resolution (0.3") observations for this project, using band 6 and the C36-4 array. This will give us ~100pc linear resolution in our targets, allowing us to resolve the inner 300pc area previous authors have found hosts the strongest IMF variation. At this resolution we are also able to resolve the sphere of influence in NGC1684, allowing direct determination of the black-hole mass (if gas is present at suitably small radii). This resolution is also well matched to our ancillary data taken with adaptive optics, providing powerful opportunities to compare and contrast results.
As discussed in detail in the sensitivity estimate part of the technical justification, the largest angular scale we expect in each 20km/s channel is 11". This is larger than the LAS resolvable in the C36-4 array, so we request an additional low resolution track with the 12m array for each object. In NGC1497 HST observations reveal a dust disk which has a minor axis size of 3 arcseconds, less than the LAS for the C36-4 array, and hence we do not request such a track here.

This galaxy has CO(2-1) observations from Davis et al., in prep (see spectrum in Figure 1). From these single dish observations we know the total flux, flux per velocity channel, and line width (listed in Table 1). We aim to map the molecular gas disc, and hence need to know its size to estimate the surface brightness. In NGC1497 HST observations reveal a dust disk 15x3 arcseconds in size, and as such dust disks are always found to be conincident with the molecular gas (Alatalo et al., 13) we use this information to estimate the sensitivity required. Experience shows that at the angular resolution we request the sources will be unresolved in each channel along the kinematic axis of the system (tracing the `spider diagram') and thus only the minor axis size is important when estimating the surface brightness sensitivity required.
In order to calculate the RMS requested we take the integrated intensity of the CO(2-1) line and divide it by the velocity width (see Table 1) to give a mean flux per channel. Spreading this flux over 10 resolution elements (resolving the minor axis size of 3" with a 0.3" beam) and requiring a 5 sigma detection gives us our requested RMS. Note we require a S/N of 5 in this object as we know the source size, while in the other objects we are assuming a maximum source size (so our real S/N will very likely be >3).
The uncertainty on the kinematic modelling we will conduct varies directly with the channel width. Thus observations with a high velocity resolution are required. We here base our sensitivity estimate on binning to 20 km/s channels, which will yield a typical uncertainty in M/L of ?0.1, allowing an accurate determination of the IMF parameters. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

As argued above we require relatively high velocity resolution. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$1.28 \kms), which we will bin up to 20 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for bright sources, or increase it to get higher sensitivity. We place our representative spectral window on 12CO(2-1) using this setup. Our lines are wide (upto 900 km/s in some cases), but will easily fit within the ~2500 km/s coverage of an individual window.
We place another band on the nearby CS line, which would provide a window on the dense gas conditions in our source (but detection of this line would be an unexpected bonus, and does not drive our time estimate). We will use 16x spectral averaging for this window to reduce the data rate, as this line is expected to be weak. In each sideband we also place a 2GHz spectral window with 31MHz (45 \kms) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

This resolution is also well matched to our ancillary data taken with adaptive optics, providing powerful opportunities to compare and contrast results.
As discussed in detail in the sensitivity estimate part of the technical justification, the largest angular scale we expect in each 20km/s channel is 11". This is larger than the LAS resolvable in the C36-4 array, so we request an additional low resolution track with the 12m array for each object. In NGC1497 HST observations reveal a dust disk which has a minor axis size of 3 arcseconds, less than the LAS for the C36-4 array, and hence we do not request such a track here.

As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

From these single dish observations we know the total flux, flux per velocity channel, and line width (listed in Table 1). We aim to map the molecular gas disc, and hence need to know its size to estimate the surface brightness. We here base our sensitivity estimate on binning to 20 km/s channels, which will yield a typical uncertainty in M/L of ?0.1, allowing an accurate determination of the IMF parameters. As discussed below, however, we retain the ability to bin more if the signal to noise is low, or unbin to obtain higher precision measurements of the molecular gas kinematics in bright regions.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe the molecular discs that lie in the heart of five of the most massive (M* > 10^11.5 Msun) early-type galaxies in the local universe with ALMA. Work by our team has shown that a non-negligible fraction of the most massive galaxies host molecular gas discs and star formation, but the origin of this material, its fate, and its effect on the host galaxy is poorly constrained. With ALMA observations we propose to shed light on this issue, while simultaneously using the relaxed kinematics of these discs to answer profound open questions in extragalactic astrophysics. For instance, the IMF of the most massive galaxies appears to vary, becoming more bottom heavy as the velocity dispersion of galaxies increases. We here propose a new, independent way to study this effect, deriving dynamical mass-to-light ratio profiles in massive ellipticals and thus constraining their IMF. The gravitational sphere of influence of the supermassive black holes in these objects are also resolvable, allowing us to constrain the demographics of massive black holes.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics, Astronomy and Mathematics, Hertfordshire, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astrophysical Sciences Department and Observatory, Princeton University
